items.title: Making Wrist Rests for My Ergonomic Keyboard
items.content_html:
About a year ago I started to notice some fatigue and pain in my hands from working at a desk all day. Eventually, I decided to splurge on a fancy split keyboard - the ZSA Voyager.

I‚Äôve been using that in addition to switching to the Colemak keyboard layout, which have both really improved my comfort while typing. Maybe the biggest change is just engaging my awareness around how my hands and body feel when I‚Äôm working at a desk. The biggest help hasn‚Äôt been one single change, but instead forming a habit of variety around my working position. I sit, stand, type wide apart, closer together, and generally try to reposition and move things throughout the day.

One new thing I added recently was some keyboard tenting, using these cheap magnetic phone stands to add a steeper angle to each of the halves of the Voyager. It‚Äôs a very different experience and it really only works when I‚Äôm standing at my desk ‚Äî sitting would require a desk so low that my legs wouldn‚Äôt fit under it. The result is undeniably different but it wasn‚Äôt immediately comfortable because you really do need to float your arms in front of the keyboard to maintain the right angle to type. This is doable for a while, but then fatigue would cause me to rest my arms down which introduced a whole new contortion and discomfort.

I looked at some wrist rests online but was once again confronted by how expensive and ugly things marketed for health, ergonomics, tech and, worst of all, the intersection of all three are. It‚Äôs just not something I was willing to invest in because‚Ä¶ well, I want to like the things around me.

So this leads me to a solution: I made some tiny pillows! My partner is super talented and practiced at sewing and I‚Äôve been wanting to learn how to sew. This was actually just a practice project to lead into a bigger sewing project, but why not practice on something useful?

The result is two small, relatively firm pillows that are filled with scrap fabric. They‚Äôre dense but not heavy, and they‚Äôre a long rectangular shape, meaning you can play around with their orientation and get different kinds of support.

Like everything else in this ergonomic journey, they‚Äôre an option. I‚Äôve found them to be super comfortable for some positions and a bit uncomfortable for others. I like to use them while typing, but for general computer use, moving back and forth from keyboard to mouse, it‚Äôs a bit cumbersome to add these into the mix.

Overall, my favourite part of these was making them. Learning to sew feels like a long-neglected life skill I‚Äôm happy to start demystifying for myself. I‚Äôm told my hand-stitching on the one seam we left open for stuffing the pillows is quite neat! I really enjoyed every step of the process.

I‚Äôve been liking Substack less and less since I first set up my newsletter there but I‚Äôve been resisting moving more so because it feels like a distraction from actually writing. I‚Äôll move eventually. And it‚Äôs shit like this that assures me I will.

When I work with clients, I push them to stop looking for an objective reason to do something creative and instead lean into what they believe. The biggest surprise about this process, to me, is how almost everyone can step up and do that. So I’m trying to do that for myself, too.

items.title: AI isn‚Äôt God - A bit about absurdity and highlighting contrasts.
items.content_html:
A few weeks ago I published a piece about how AI is showing up in everything, even Adobe Acrobat. It‚Äôs now well beyond ridiculous, and the one thing I didn‚Äôt articulate with words but explored a bit with visuals is the absolutely hilarious way that AI is elevated to this omnipotent, god-like status – it‚Äôs something so powerful and dangerous that we don‚Äôt understand how incredible it is – but then we use it to do some of the most mundane, trivial shit. It‚Äôs like asking Jesus to put together your IKEA for you.

People much smarter than me have pointed out how AI evangelists speak about ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù (Artificial General Intelligence) and technology in general with a fully religious fervour. It‚Äôs part of what is so off-putting about AI tools to me. Like Web3, crypto, NFTs and basically any other cyber-cult there‚Äôs this uncritical dogma circling AI that forces you to accept certain things as fact before you can even join the conversation. And I just don‚Äôt. It doesn‚Äôt follow, to me, that a sufficiently complex auto-complete text generator will somehow ascend toward full god-level intelligence. I don‚Äôt believe it. And because I don‚Äôt believe that everything that follows is just impossible to believe.

Conversely, the people that do accept the dogma now have a solid logical framework for everything else to build off of. It makes perfect sense that every business will want to integrate AI into their products and their workflows – who wouldn‚Äôt want a GOD on their side?

This is where the absurdity of the comparison slots into place for me. I just don‚Äôt get how we can ask god to do our homework for us. I don‚Äôt understand how it seems like a good use of a cyber-deity to summarize an email for you. It reminds me of when I watch Survivor and people are praying to god to save them from being voted out. Is that a good use of your god‚Äôs infinite, transcendent power and influence? To keep you on a game show?

Anyways, this whole rant was just meant to set up the rationale behind the images I made to go with that recent post. I discovered these amazing prints on The Public Domain Review and when I thought of contrasting them with the meaningless word trash Adobe created to promote Acrobat AI, it felt too funny not to try it out.

I really love how lame the marketing language looks when you pair it with literal biblical imagery.

Working on Everyone‚Äôs Creative has been interesting in how it‚Äôs helped me widen what I let myself create for the newsletter. Before, when it was still Robot Fan Club it felt very closely tied to my identity as an illustrator. I felt a real pressure (from myself) to draw a lot of the imagery I used to support the writing. Sometimes it worked really well! Sometimes I was clearly less into it. With this new name and framing, though, I feel way more free to play with design, collage, typography and visual metaphor in a way that has been a lot of fun. The visual identity that is growing around Everyone‚Äôs Creative is really energizing me.

I‚Äôm looking forward to experimenting more with the art I make for EC. It feels like a new ‚Äúera‚Äù for my work and I feel so much more excited about making things recently than I have in a long time. Turns out I like novelty!
